commit_message:
add basic rst sanity checker

does the spec file end in .rst and does it wrap at 80 columns for
readability.

Change-Id: I48352a1d79f38df936f424bf9290430c0258d79d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/qa-specs refs/changes/47/81347/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/python # Copyright 2014 Samsung Electronics # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import argparse import fileinput import os import re import sys ERRORS = 0 def error(msg): global ERRORS ERRORS += 1 print(msg) def get_options(): parser = argparse.ArgumentParser( description='RST sanity checker') parser.add_argument('-d', '--dir', help="Specifications Directory", default="specs") return parser.parse_args() def find_rst_files(dirname): files = [] for root, dirnames, filenames in os.walk(dirname): for f in filenames: if f != ".keep": files.append("%s/%s" % (root, f)) return files def ensure_files_end_in_rst(files): for fname in files: if not re.search("\.rst$", fname): error("E001: Filename %s does not end in .rst" % fname) def ensure_lt80(files): for fname in files: for line in fileinput.input(fname): if len(line) > 80: error("E002: File %s exceeds 80 columns" % fname) def main(): opts = get_options() files = find_rst_files(opts.dir) ensure_files_end_in_rst(files) ensure_lt80(files) if ERRORS > 0: return 1 return 0 if __name__ == "__main__": sys.exit(main())

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-chef-repo refs/changes/09/83809/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This repository contains examples of the roles, environments and other supporting files for deploying an OpenStack **Icehouse** reference architecture using Chef. This currently includes all OpenStack core projects: Compute, Dashboard, Identity, Image, Network, Object Storage, Block Storage, Telemetry and Orchestration. Development of the latest Stable release will continue on the `master` branch and releases tagged with `9.0.X`. Once development starts against OpenStack `master` or `juno`, this branch will move to `stable/icehouse` and the appropriate branches will continue development.The cookbooks have been designed and written in such a way that they can be used to deploy individual service components on _any_ of the nodes in the infrastructure; in short they can be used for single node 'all-in-one' installs (for testing), right up to multi/many node production installs. In order to achieve this flexibility, they are configured by attributes which may be used to override search. Chef 11 or later is currently required. Ruby 1.9.x is considered the minimum supported version of Ruby as well. Most users of this repository test with the full-stack Chef 11 client and a Chef server (Chef Solo is not explicity supported).
deleted_lines: This repository contains examples of the roles, environments and other supporting files for deploying an OpenStack **Havana** reference architecture using Chef. This currently includes all OpenStack core projects: Compute, Dashboard, Identity, Image, Network, Object Storage, Block Storage, Telemetry and Orchestration. Development of the latest Stable release will continue on the `master` branch and releases tagged with `8.0.X`. Once development starts against OpenStack `master` or `icehouse`, this branch will move to `stable/havana` and the appropriate branches will continue development.The cookbooks have been designed and written in such a way that they can be used to deploy individual service components on _any_ of the nodes in the infrastructure; in short they can be used for single node 'all-in-one' installs (for testing), right up to multi/many node production installs. In order to achieve this flexibility, they are configured by attributes which may be used to override search. Chef 10 or later is currently required, but the intention is to [move to Chef 11 with the `havana` release](https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-chef/+bug/1183540) to take advantage of features such as [partial search](http://docs.opscode.com/essentials_search_partial.html). Ruby 1.9.x is considered the minimum supported version of Ruby as well. Most users of this repository test with the full-stack Chef 11 client and a Chef server (Chef Solo is not explicity supported).

commit_message:
Script to generate test cases according to pairwise methodology

The script should be adjusted before using. You may
change parameters and rules lists to do it.

You need to install following python package:
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/AllPairs/2.0.1

Run it as ordinary python script. Generated test cases
will be printed in stdout as a list of parameters
combinations.

Change-Id: I1bce9d8bfd5cb20a266fc4f1d7b285889d9c3d7d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/86/81786/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import metacomm.combinatorics.all_pairs2 all_pairs = metacomm.combinatorics.all_pairs2.all_pairs2 parameters = [ #("os", ["CentOS", "RedHat", "Ubuntu"]), ("mode", ["simple", "HA"]), ("controller", [1, 3]), ("compute", [1, 2]), ("cinder", [1, 2, 0]), ("ceph", [2, 3, 0]), ("network", ["nova flat", "nova vlan", "neutron GRE", "neutron VLAN"]), ("tagging", ["yes", "no"]), ("storage volume", ["default", "ceph"]), ("storage images", ["default", "ceph"]), ("savanna", ["yes", "no"]), ("murano", ["yes", "no"]), ("ceilometer", ["yes", "no"]) ] def is_valid_combination(values, names): dictionary = dict(zip(names, values)) """ Should return True if combination is valid and False otherwise. Dictionary that is passed here can be incomplete. To prevent search for unnecessary items filtering function is executed with found subset of data to validate it. """ rules = [ lambda d: "RedHat" == d["os"] and "ceph" == d["storage volume"] , lambda d: "RedHat" == d["os"] and "ceph" == d["storage images"] , lambda d: "RedHat" == d["os"] and "yes" == d["savanna"] , lambda d: "RedHat" == d["os"] and "yes" == d["murano"] , lambda d: "RedHat" == d["os"] and "neutron GRE" == d["network"] , lambda d: "RedHat" == d["os"] and "neutron VLAN" == d["network"] , lambda d: d["cinder"] > 0 and d["storage volume"] == "default" , lambda d: d["ceph"] > 0 and d["storage volume"] == "default" and d["storage images"] == "default" ] for rule in rules: try: if rule(dictionary): return False except KeyError: pass return True pairwise = all_pairs( [x[1] for x in parameters] , filter_func=lambda values: is_valid_combination(values, [x[0] for x in parameters]) ) for i, v in enumerate(pairwise): print "%i:\t%s" % (i, v)

commit_message:
Handling validation in conductor consistently

Change where we do validation in change_node_power_state to follow
where we do it for do_node_deploy and vendor_passthrough. That
is, we perform validation synchronously before we spawn off a
thread to perform the longer running action.

Change-Id: Ic1f791bb5ef49c033e4baff8d3f6900091dbf332
Closes-bug: #1294676

This hack is made to * fix the alignment of two table, needs a better solution in the * future. */ ul.breadcrumb { padding-left: 0px; border-top-left-radius: 0px; border-bottom-left-radius: 0px; border-left: none; li { visibility: hidden; } } } table { border-collapse: collapse; thead { tr th { border-bottom: none; background-color: @grayLighter; } } tbody { tr:last-child td { border-bottom: 1px solid #ddd; border-radius: 0; } tr.empty td { height: @tdHeight; padding: @actionsColumnPadding; } td.actions_column { position: static; } } } .breadcrumb{ padding: 6px; margin: 0 0 1px 0; } }

subject: GET details REST API next link missing 'details'
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-31 20:34:40.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/api/v2/views/volumes.py', 'cinder/api/common.py', 'cinder/tests/api/v2/test_volumes.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/2981cdbb03c6f1239a58fedb260796667b8154ab', 'message': 'GET details REST API next link missing 'details'

When executing a pagination query a "next" link is included in the
API reply when there are more items then the specified limit.

See pagination documentation for more information:
http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-compute/2/content/
Paginated_Collections-d1e664.html

The caller should be able to invoke the "next" link (without
having to re-format it) in order to get the next page of data.
The documentation states "Subsequent links will honor the
initial page size. Thus, a client may follow links to traverse
a paginated collection without having to input the marker parameter."

The problem is that the "next" link is always scoped to the non-
detailed query.

For example, if you execute "/v2/<tenant>/volumes/detail?limit=1",
the "next" link does not have the URL for a detailed query and is
formatted as "/v2/<tenant>/volumes?limit=1&marker=<marker>". In this
case the "next" link needs to be scoped to "/v2/<tenant>/volumes/detail".

The user could work around this issue my manually inserting '/details'
into the "next" link URL.

Test code is included to verify that the '/details' URL is correctly added
when the "next" link is included in a detailed pagination query. Also,
existing tests were changed to ensure that the correct controller function
(ie, 'index' vs. 'detail) are invoked for the appropriate query
(ie, non-detailed or detailed) -- 'index' was previously alwayed invoked
for detailed URL requests.

Change-Id: Ib00d6deb25255fac1db0f7bf4ecd3c8d30e1c39d
Closes-bug: 1299247
'}]
commit_message:
GET details REST API next link missing 'details'

When executing a pagination query a "next" link is included in the
API reply when there are more items then the specified limit.

See pagination documentation for more information:
http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-compute/2/content/
Paginated_Collections-d1e664.html

The caller should be able to invoke the "next" link (without
having to re-format it) in order to get the next page of data.
The documentation states "Subsequent links will honor the
initial page size. Thus, a client may follow links to traverse
a paginated collection without having to input the marker parameter."

The problem is that the "next" link is always scoped to the non-
detailed query.

For example, if you execute "/v2/<tenant>/volumes/detail?limit=1",
the "next" link does not have the URL for a detailed query and is
formatted as "/v2/<tenant>/volumes?limit=1&marker=<marker>". In this
case the "next" link needs to be scoped to "/v2/<tenant>/volumes/detail".

The user could work around this issue my manually inserting '/details'
into the "next" link URL.

Test code is included to verify that the '/details' URL is correctly added
when the "next" link is included in a detailed pagination query. Also,
existing tests were changed to ensure that the correct controller function
(ie, 'index' vs. 'detail) are invoked for the appropriate query
(ie, non-detailed or detailed) -- 'index' was previously alwayed invoked
for detailed URL requests.

Change-Id: Ib00d6deb25255fac1db0f7bf4ecd3c8d30e1c39d
Closes-bug: 1299247

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-09 16:54:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/commit/bc1325cf1d76e4e619f00c095213d4e38faa393a', 'message': "Fix libssl/crypto symlinks on Fedora

Fedora does not have the 1.0.0 versions of the .so files so the
symlink step isn't working correctly.  This change looks for both
the 1.0.0 and 1.0.1e that exists on Fedora and uses whichever it
finds.

Change-Id: I8402d05be684337df70d8f48e6d2ac1ecc69eaf7
Related-Bug: #1304629
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-04-09 18:13:10.000000000', 'files': ['elements/mysql/install.d/20-galera-libssl-symlink'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/commit/adf7b081ee0074def5a36d5c63c686ef90a4d7f1', 'message': "Fix libssl/crypto symlinks on Fedora

Fedora does not have the 1.0.0 versions of the .so files, so the
existing symlink step isn't working correctly.  This change looks
for any 1.0.* versions of libssl and libcrypto, so we shouldn't have
to update it for every minor version bump but it also won't
unintentionally pull in an incompatible version.

Change-Id: I8402d05be684337df70d8f48e6d2ac1ecc69eaf7
Related-Bug: #1304629
"}]
commit_message:
Fix libssl/crypto symlinks on Fedora

Fedora does not have the 1.0.0 versions of the .so files, so the
existing symlink step isn't working correctly.  This change looks
for any 1.0.* versions of libssl and libcrypto, so we shouldn't have
to update it for every minor version bump but it also won't
unintentionally pull in an incompatible version.

Change-Id: I8402d05be684337df70d8f48e6d2ac1ecc69eaf7
Related-Bug: #1304629
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/94/86394/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [ -e $LIB_PREFIX/libssl.so.1.0.0 ]; then LIBSSL_FILE=libssl.so.1.0.0 elif [ -e $LIB_PREFIX/libssl.so.1.0.1e ]; then LIBSSL_FILE=libssl.so.1.0.1e else echo "Unable to find libssl" exit 1 fi if [ -e $LIB_PREFIX/libcrypto.so.1.0.0 ]; then LIBCRYPTO_FILE=libcrypto.so.1.0.0 elif [ -e $LIB_PREFIX/libcrypto.so.1.0.1e ]; then LIBCRYPTO_FILE=libcrypto.so.1.0.1e else echo "Unable to find libcrypto" exit 1 fi ln -s $LIB_PREFIX/$LIBSSL_FILE $LIB_PREFIX/libssl.so.6 ln -s $LIB_PREFIX/$LIBCRYPTO_FILE $LIB_PREFIX/libcrypto.so.6

commit_message:
Moved property listing into CLI

Moved listings for property keys and values into the CLI.
Removed listing from Image, and replaced with reference.
Edited Image Guide section, and added Compute config and
image-show example.

Partial-Bug: #1304114

Change-Id: I84bd59bab2eda16adbe80641fcb95c55959f5d9d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/45/86245/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
]> Image Service property keys The following keys, together with the components to which they are specific, can be used with the option for both the glance image-update and glance image-create commands. For example: $ glance image-update img-uuid --property architecture=x86_64
Property keys
Specific to Key Description Supported values
All architecture The CPU architecture that must be supported by the hypervisor. For example, x86_64, arm, or ppc64. Run uname -m to get the architecture of a machine. We strongly recommend using the architecture data vocabulary defined by the libosinfo project for this purpose. alpha — DEC 64-bit RISC armv7l — ARM Cortex-A7 MPCore cris — Ethernet, Token Ring, AXis — Code Reduced Instruction Set i686 — Intel sixth-generation x86 (P6 micro architecture) ia64 — Itanium lm32 — Lattice Micro32 m68k — Motorola 68000 microblaze — Xilinx 32-bit FPGA (Big Endian) microblazeel — Xilinx 32-bit FPGA (Little Endian) mips — MIPS 32-bit RISC (Big Endian) mipsel — MIPS 32-bit RISC (Little Endian) mips64 — MIPS 64-bit RISC (Big Endian) mips64el — MIPS 64-bit RISC (Little Endian) openrisc — OpenCores RISC parisc — HP Precision Architecture RISC parisc64 — HP Precision Architecture 64-bit RISC ppc — PowerPC 32-bit ppc64 — PowerPC 64-bit ppcemb — PowerPC (Embedded 32-bit) s390 — IBM Enterprise Systems Architecture/390 s390x — S/390 64-bit sh4 — SuperH SH-4 (Little Endian) sh4eb — SuperH SH-4 (Big Endian) sparc — Scalable Processor Architecture, 32-bit sparc64 — Scalable Processor Architecture, 64-bit unicore32 — Microprocessor Research and Development Center RISC Unicore32 x86_64 — 64-bit extension of IA-32 xtensa — Tensilica Xtensa configurable microprocessor core xtensaeb — Tensilica Xtensa configurable microprocessor core (Big Endian)
All hypervisor_type The hypervisor type. xen, qemu, kvm, lxc, uml, vmware, or hyperv
All instance_uuid For snapshot images, this is the UUID of the server used to create this image. Valid server UUID
All kernel_id The ID of an image stored in the Image Service that should be used as the kernel when booting an AMI-style image. Valid image ID
All os_distro The common name of the operating system distribution in lowercase (uses the same data vocabulary as the libosinfo project). Specify only a recognized value for this field. Deprecated values are listed to assist you in searching for the recognized value. arch — Arch Linux. Do not use archlinux or org.archlinux centos — Community Enterprise Operating System. Do not use org.centos or CentOS debian — Debian. Do not use Debian or org.debian fedora — Fedora. Do not use Fedora, org.fedora, or org.fedoraproject freebsd — FreeBSD. Do not use org.freebsd, freeBSD, or FreeBSD gentoo — Gentoo Linux. Do not use Gentoo or org.gentoo mandrake — Mandrakelinux (MandrakeSoft) distribution. Do not use mandrakelinux or MandrakeLinux mandriva — Mandriva Linux. Do not use mandrivalinux mes — Mandriva Enterprise Server. Do not use mandrivaent or mandrivaES msdos — Microsoft Disc Operating System. Do not use ms-dos netbsd — NetBSD. Do not use NetBSD or org.netbsd netware — Novell NetWare. Do not use novell or NetWare openbsd — OpenBSD. Do not use OpenBSD or org.openbsd opensolaris — OpenSolaris. Do not use OpenSolaris or org.opensolaris opensuse — openSUSE. Do not use suse, SuSE, or org.opensuse rhel — Red Hat Enterprise Linux. Do not use redhat, RedHat, or com.redhat sled — SUSE Linux Enterprise Desktop. Do not use com.suse ubuntu — Ubuntu. Do not use Ubuntu, com.ubuntu, org.ubuntu, or canonical windows — Microsoft Windows. Do not use com.microsoft.server or windoze
All os_version The operating system version as specified by the distributor. Version number (for example, "11.10")
All ramdisk_id The ID of image stored in the Image Service that should be used as the ramdisk when booting an AMI-style image. Valid image ID
All vm_mode The virtual machine mode. This represents the host/guest ABI (application binary interface) used for the virtual machine. hvm — Fully virtualized. This is the mode used by QEMU and KVM. xen — Xen 3.0 paravirtualized. uml — User Mode Linux paravirtualized. exe — Executables in containers. This is the mode used by LXC.
libvirt API driver hw_video_model The video image driver used. vga, cirrus, vmvga, xen, or qxl
VMware API driver vmware_adaptertype The virtual SCSI or IDE controller used by the hypervisor. lsiLogic, busLogic, or ide
VMware API driver vmware_ostype A VMware GuestID which describes the operating system installed in the image. This value is passed to the hypervisor when creating a virtual machine. If not specified, the key defaults to otherGuest. See thinkvirt.com.
VMware API driver vmware_image_version Currently unused. 1
XenAPI driver auto_disk_config If true, the root partition on the disk is automatically resized before the instance boots. This value is only taken into account by the Compute service when using a Xen-based hypervisor with the XenAPI driver. The Compute service will only attempt to resize if there is a single partition on the image, and only if the partition is in ext3 or ext4 format. true | false
XenAPI driver os_type The operating system installed on the image. The XenAPI driver contains logic that takes different actions depending on the value of the os_type parameter of the image. For example, for os_type=windows images, it creates a FAT32-based swap partition instead of a Linux swap partition, and it limits the injected host name to less than 16 characters. linux or windows

commit_message:
Fix for rabbitmq3.

Send data in next EventMachine loop. Without this, sending hangs for 10 minutes.

Closes-Bug: #1278336
Change-Id: Ic2dbe4e7a922243573b38ac4a43e91d8156c2132

commit_message:
Add unit tests for commands

This commit adds commands function.

Partially implements bp unit-tests

Change-Id: If5e037546965e338ebb9a171a178826b4e3136d6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/72/79572/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 NEC Corporation. All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os from tempest.common import commands from tempest.tests import base class TestCommands(base.TestCase): def test_ip_addr_raw(self): actual = commands.ip_addr_raw() self.assertIsInstance(actual, str) expected = os.execvp('sudo', ['sudo', 'ip', 'a']) self.assertEqual(expected, actual) def test_ip_route_raw(self): actual = commands.ip_route_raw() self.assertIsInstance(actual, str) expected = os.execvp('sudo', ['sudo', 'ip', 'r']) self.assertEqual(expected, actual) def test_ip_ns_raw(self): actual = commands.ip_ns_raw() self.assertIsInstance(actual, str) expected = os.execvp('sudo', ['sudo', 'ip', 'netns', 'list']) self.assertEqual(expected, actual) def test_iptables_raw(self): table = 'filter' actual = commands.iptables_raw(table) self.assertIsInstance(actual, str) expected = os.execvp('sudo', ['iptables', '-v', '-S', '-t', '%s' % table]) self.assertEqual(expected, actual) def test_ip_ns_list(self): actual = commands.ip_ns_list() self.assertIsInstance(actual, list) expected = os.execvp('sudo', ['sudo', 'ip', 'netns', 'list']).split() self.assertEqual(expected, actual) def test_ip_ns_addr(self): ns_list = commands.ip_ns_list() for ns in ns_list: actual = commands.ip_ns_addr(ns) self.assertIsInstance(actual, str) expected = os.execvp('sudo', ['sudo', 'ip', 'netns', 'exec', '%s', 'ip a' % ns]) self.assertEqual(expected, actual) def test_ip_ns_route(self): ns_list = commands.ip_ns_list() for ns in ns_list: actual = commands.ip_ns_route(ns) self.assertIsInstance(actual, str) expected = os.execvp('sudo', ['sudo', 'ip', 'netns', 'exec', '%s', 'ip r' % ns]) self.assertEqual(expected, actual) def test_iptables_ns(self): table = 'filter' ns_list = commands.iptables_ns() for ns in ns_list: actual = commands.iptables_ns(ns, table) self.assertIsInstance(actual, str) expected = os.execvp('sudo', ['sudo', 'ip', 'netns', 'exec', '%s', 'iptables -v -S -t', '%s' % (ns, table)]) self.assertEqual(expected, actual)

commit_message:
Make libvirt volume pool configurable

Currently volume pool defaults to 'default'. This patch allows
specifying a custom pool so that storage limitations can be overcome.

Change-Id: I85762dc91f9f6ea479edb777fdb7a5618fbb9b9e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/09/83409/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LIBVIRT_VOL_POOL=${LIBVIRT_VOL_POOL:-"default"} for NAME in $(sudo virsh vol-list $LIBVIRT_VOL_POOL 2>/dev/null | grep /var/ | awk '{print $1}' | grep "^\(seed\(.*\|\)|baremetal\(\|brbm.*\)-\)" ); do sudo virsh vol-delete --pool $LIBVIRT_VOL_POOL $NAME
deleted_lines: for NAME in $(sudo virsh vol-list default 2>/dev/null | grep /var/ | awk '{print $1}' | grep "^\(seed\(.*\|\)|baremetal\(\|brbm.*\)-\)" ); do sudo virsh vol-delete --pool default $NAME

commit_message:
Update swift-container-info to be storage policy aware

Lookup policy name in swift.conf; 'Legacy' container will use
policy-0's name; 'Unknown' is shown if policy not found in swift.conf

Change-Id: I450d40dc6e2d8f759187dff36d658e52737ae2a5

commit_message:
Correct update to zero numbers of health monitors

If property 'monitors' is in prop_diff and equals to None ot [],
we should not skip dissociating step for monitors.

Change-Id: I313a8e09dbeeab78126ff889316f0ecb1a9a8c84
Closes-Bug: #1301406

Change-Id: If457f5e264c5d1aef8ede7844cef36751a98ae73
'}]
commit_message:
Introduce a path for accessing the current user

This will help with a lot of client side interaction because it means
the client will not need to know the user_id of the currently
authenticated user.

Change-Id: If457f5e264c5d1aef8ede7844cef36751a98ae73
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack-attic/identity-api refs/changes/73/81973/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - Operations on the current user can be performed at /v3/user.#### Current User: `/v3/user` *New in version 3.3* Actions involving the user that has been authenticated can be performed without having to know the user's entity id. A request for `/user` is treated exactly the same as a request to `/users/{userid}` where `{userid}` is the entity id of the current user as identified by the authentication data from the token. This includes handling of paths that are based on the user object. For example the `List user projects` URL is typically found at `GET /users/{user_id}/projects` however a user wishing to list there own projects can retrieve the exact same response at `GET /user/projects`.

commit_message:
Add an automated naming convention for UNIQUEs

For operating with UniqueConstraint names are needed, however these
names are in most cases generated by database in use, when the
constraint is created without name.

Omitting names when creating unique constraints leads to two problems:
1. UC name will be different for each database backend
(so we can't e.g. easily drop it in a migration script).
2. _raise_duplicate_error() depends on the specific format of UCs names
to return column names correctly.

Until we move to using SQLAlchemy 0.9, the implementation for
`remove_naming_conventions` can not be designed.

Change-Id: I5558ae6e7e1db2a50875641f551eef7360708e01
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/91/73191/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _unique_constraint_check_name(target, parent): constrain_name = 'uniq_%s' % target.table.name for column in target.columns: constrain_name += '0%s' % column.name if not hasattr(target, 'name') or target.name != constrain_name: target.name = constrain_name def apply_naming_conventions(): """Apply naming conventions to constraints name.""" sqlalchemy.event.listens_for( sqlalchemy.UniqueConstraint, 'after_parent_attach')(_unique_constraint_check_name)

commit_message:
keystone::wsgi::apache install dependancy python-paste-deploy

On Redhat/CentOS, python-paste-deploy is not installed as a dependancy of
other packages.

The WSGI scripts fails outlining it can not import paste deploy

This ensures that it is installed by default

Params for both Redhat and Ubuntu packages are listed for completeness
and less conditionals

Change-Id: Iadc9cc9cb926a57cb75d9002a6a81f589201fc63
Implements: package install

commit_message:
Make stack.sh failing if SELinux is enforcing

On Fedora 20, starting rabbitmq-server.service fills
/var/log/audit/audit.log and then fails because the SELinux policy of
RabbitMQ doesn't allow to listen on an ephemeral port.

Until the bug is fixed in Fedora, I propose to make the stack.sh failing
to warn the user of the bug with a message explaining the bug and how to
workaround it. In my opinion, it's more convinient than adding a note
somewhere in DevStack website or DevStack documentation.

Example of audit logs:

type=SYSCALL msg=audit(1396364497.544:136306): arch=c000003e syscall=49
success=no exit=-13 a0=10 a1=7f2badca1980 a2=1c a3=1 items=0 ppid=1
pid=32383 auid=4294967295 uid=998 gid=997 euid=998 suid=998 fsuid=998
egid=997 sgid=997 fsgid=997 ses=4294967295 tty=(none) comm="beam.smp"
exe="/usr/lib64/erlang/erts-5.10.4/bin/beam.smp"
subj=system_u:system_r:rabbitmq_beam_t:s0 key=(null)

type=AVC msg=audit(1396364497.544:136307): avc:  denied  { name_bind }
for  pid=32383 comm="beam.smp" src=30839
scontext=system_u:system_r:rabbitmq_beam_t:s0
tcontext=system_u:object_r:unreserved_port_t:s0 tclass=tcp_socket

Change-Id: If718d74e559c6050cbc7786dc6da74c4847b6328
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/82/84482/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [ "$(/usr/sbin/getenforce 2>/dev/null)" = "Enforcing" ]; then echo "DevStack doesn't support SELinux in Enforce mode yet because of this RabbitMQ bug:" echo "https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1032595" echo "https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=998682" echo echo "Set SELINUX=permissive in /etc/selinux/config to workaround this issue" exit 1 fi

subject: Provide a keystone.conf for tempest
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-23 15:10:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/bfdef6a744e1a9eb8b1bf062b4a6f650411a00d1', 'message': "Make keystone.conf world readable

The keystone.conf file was set to 0600 and only the user could
read it. The user that Tempest runs as could not read it and a test
for `keystone-manage db_version` would fail because it can't read
the config file.

The keystone.conf file will now be 644 so that the Tempest user
can read it and we can add tests for keystone-manage.

The keystone.conf file should now match the nova.conf file
permissions. There are already tests for nova-manage in Tempest.

Change-Id: I4ce406f32189a81c6a7361a11dc474886629b806
Closes-Bug: #1284341
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-03-25 02:06:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/46e87808718bf17a50aa39dd739bc2abcb8cfc78', 'message': "Provide a keystone.conf for tempest

The keystone.conf file isn't readable by the tempest user so it
can't run commands like `keystone-manage db_version`. This is for
security reasons.

This change adds a keystone.tempest.conf file that tempest has
access to. It only has the database connection string (so it
doesn't include the admin token or ldap password).

Closes-Bug: #1284341
Change-Id: I4ce406f32189a81c6a7361a11dc474886629b806

commit_message:
Provide a keystone.conf for tempest

The keystone.conf file isn't readable by the tempest user so it
can't run commands like `keystone-manage db_version`. This is for
security reasons.

This change adds a keystone.tempest.conf file that tempest has
access to. It only has the database connection string (so it
doesn't include the admin token or ldap password).

Closes-Bug: #1284341
Change-Id: I4ce406f32189a81c6a7361a11dc474886629b806
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/58/82358/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: chmod 644 $KEYSTONE_CONF

commit_message:
Default project quota flavor

This blueprint is to define a default quota flavor for a specific
project.

The main use for this is to set up a quota flavor used to configure by
default the project user quotas when the user is created.

Related to blueprint default-quota-flavor.

Change-Id: I2529a97abcccc5fe07c9158c1f96c2c1883bf863
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/21/84521/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================ Default project quota flavor ============================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/default-quota-flavor This blueprint is to define a default quota flavor for a specific project. The main use for this is to set up a quota flavor used to configure by default the project user quotas when the user is created. Problem description =================== Currently when an operator creates a new user, the quotas have to be configured manually one by one based on the user requirements. This blueprint comes from the operators feedback: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/operators-feedback-mar14 -> line 448 Proposed change =============== To add a relation between a quota flavor and a project. This will be used during the user creation process to define the user quotas. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- Add this table to the db: Model DefaultProjectQuotaFlavor """Represents the relation between a project and a quota flavor""" +------------------+------------+----------+-------+ | Name | Type | Nullable | PK | +==================+============+==========+=======+ | id | Integer | False | True | +------------------+------------+----------+-------+ | tenant_id | String(255)| False | False | +------------------+------------+----------+-------+ | quota_flavor_id | String(255)| False | False | +------------------+------------+----------+-------+ REST API impact --------------- Get Default Quota Flavor ************************ * Method: GET * Path: /os-quota-flavors/default/{tenant_id} * Desc: Shows the default quota flavors for a tenant * Resp: Normal Response Codes 200 +------------+-------+--------+-----------------------------------------------+ | Parameter | Style | Type | Desc | +============+=======+========+===============================================+ | tenant_id | URI | string | The ID for the tenant for which you want to | | | | | list the default quota flavor | +------------+-------+--------+-----------------------------------------------+ Set Quota Flavor ******************* * Method: PUT * Path: os-quota-flavors/default/{tenant_id} * Desc: Set a quota flavor as default for a specific tenant * Resp: Normal Response Codes 200 +------------+-------+--------+-----------------------------------------------+ | Parameter | Style | Type | Desc | +============+=======+========+===============================================+ | tenant_id | URI | string | The ID for the tenant for which you want to | | | | | associate the quota flavor | +------------+-------+--------+-----------------------------------------------+ | flavor_name| plain | string | The name for the flavor to be set as default | +------------+-------+--------+-----------------------------------------------+ Update Quota Flavor ******************* * Method: POST * Path: os-quota-flavors/default/{tenant_id} * Desc: Updates a quota flavor as default for a specific tenant * Resp: Normal Response Codes 200 +------------+-------+--------+-----------------------------------------------+ | Parameter | Style | Type | Desc | +============+=======+========+===============================================+ | tenant_id | URI | string | The ID for the tenant for which you want to | | | | | associate the quota flavor | +------------+-------+--------+-----------------------------------------------+ | flavor_name| plain | string | The name for the flavor to be set as default | +------------+-------+--------+-----------------------------------------------+ Delete Quota Flavor ******************* * Method: DELETE * Path: os-quota-flavors/default/{tenant_id} * Desc: Deletes a default quota flavor for a tenant * Resp: Normal Response Codes 200 +------------+-------+--------+-----------------------------------------------+ | Parameter | Style | Type | Desc | +============+=======+========+===============================================+ | tenant_id | URI | string | The ID for the tenant for which you want to | | | | | delete the default quota flavor | +------------+-------+--------+-----------------------------------------------+ Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- This change affects the client user interface. The following commands are added: quota-flavor-default --tenant-id <tenant_id> quota-flavor-default-update --tenant-id <tenant_id> --flavor-name <flavor_name> quota-flavor-default-delete --tenant-id <tenant_id> Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: sergio-j-cazzolato Other contributors: gseverina Work Items ---------- None Dependencies ============ Depends on blueprint quota-flavors Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation needed for: * Rest API * Client Interface References ========== Link to notes from a summit session: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/operators-feedback-mar14 -> line 448

commit_message:
Fix incorrect attribute name during re-register

Pass the correct base class attribute name for host topic to self.register
and fix the AttributeError seen while starting conductor service

Fixes bug #1246308

Change-Id: I25848c2744473eddfd4c3a7aa5c127be74b65c97
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/55/54555/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
heat configure auth_token for v3 keystone

Because heat now creates users in a non-default domain, we need
to ensure auth_token uses the v3 keystone API, otherwise tokens
owned by the stack-domain-users created by heat will be denied
access to the heat API.

For folks still using the v2 API there is a HEAT_IDENTITY_API_VERSION
variable, which can be set to "2.0" to return to v2 settings.

Change-Id: I70cde0ffb437a949b6a1e8caa54c4db458df1e48
Related-Bug: #1291097
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/41/80341/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [[ $api_version == '3.0' ]]; then iniset $conf_file keystone_authtoken auth_uri $KEYSTONE_SERVICE_PROTOCOL://$KEYSTONE_SERVICE_HOST:$KEYSTONE_SERVICE_PORT/v3 iniset $conf_file keystone_authtoken auth_version 'v3.0' else iniset $conf_file keystone_authtoken auth_uri $KEYSTONE_SERVICE_PROTOCOL://$KEYSTONE_SERVICE_HOST:$KEYSTONE_SERVICE_PORT/v$api_version fi

commit_message:
Allow outputs to be specified as hidden

This makes it possible for a user to mark an output as hidden, so that
the value of the output is obfuscated when the stack is shown.

The idea is to later add functionality that will allow a user to pass
a parameter that shows hidden parameters. For example, users could
mark password values as hidden, and then only show them when they
specify with the parameter

Co-Authored-By: Richard Lee <rblee88@gmail.com>
Implements: blueprint add-hidden-attribute-to-outputs
Change-Id: I370a25165c91b119c6600283cddd32ee5e930b3f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/38/75238/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_format_stack_outputs(self): self.stack.output = mock.Mock(return_value='foobar') outputs = {'foo': {'Description': 'its a foo'}} fmt_outputs = api.format_stack_outputs(self.stack, outputs) self.assertEqual(1, len(fmt_outputs)) output = fmt_outputs[0] self.assertEqual('its a foo', output[rpc_api.OUTPUT_DESCRIPTION]) self.assertEqual('foobar', output[rpc_api.OUTPUT_VALUE]) self.assertEqual('foo', output[rpc_api.OUTPUT_KEY]) def test_format_stack_outputs_hidden_true(self): self.stack.output = mock.Mock(return_value='foobar') outputs = {'foo': {'hidden': True}} fmt_outputs = api.format_stack_outputs(self.stack, outputs) output = fmt_outputs[0] self.assertEqual(api.HIDDEN_VALUE, output[rpc_api.OUTPUT_VALUE]) def test_format_stack_outputs_hidden_false(self): self.stack.output = mock.Mock(return_value='foobar') outputs = {'foo': {'hidden': False}} fmt_outputs = api.format_stack_outputs(self.stack, outputs) output = fmt_outputs[0] self.assertEqual('foobar', output[rpc_api.OUTPUT_VALUE]) def test_format_stack_outputs_hidden_not_present(self): self.stack.output = mock.Mock(return_value='foobar') outputs = {'foo': {}} fmt_outputs = api.format_stack_outputs(self.stack, outputs) output = fmt_outputs[0] self.assertEqual('foobar', output[rpc_api.OUTPUT_VALUE]) def test_format_stack_outputs_no_description(self): self.stack.output = mock.Mock(return_value='foobar') outputs = {'foo': {}} fmt_outputs = api.format_stack_outputs(self.stack, outputs) output = fmt_outputs[0] self.assertEqual('No description given', output[rpc_api.OUTPUT_DESCRIPTION]) def test_format_string_hidden_true(self): self.assertEqual(api.HIDDEN_VALUE, api.format_string('foo', True)) def test_format_string_hidden_false(self): self.assertEqual('foo', api.format_string('foo', False)) def test_format_string_hidden_defaults_to_false(self): self.assertEqual('foo', api.format_string('foo'))

commit_message:
Implements: Security group record in Server Details included Name & description as a optinal arguments.
            Now if you want to create security-group, there is no need to add name & description as complulsory parameters.
            Just run nova secgroup-create, it will create group with id/UUID for nova-network & neutron.
Closes-Bug: #1254722

Change-Id: If9fa245ba11e0a6df727dfd10810fb97ee3124d9

commit_message:
Import distributed port groups into neutron DB

This change is to add a method into vcenter neutron agent
to sync distributed port groups into openstack, and map
them to network objects in neutron for vm deployments usage.

Change-Id: Ica50e69956f0c311b53b82bd52b7929047e8255a
Implements: blueprint vcenter-neutron-agent

added_lines: # self._setup_rpc() def import_dvs_port_groups(self): LOG.info("Start to import distributed port group in cluster %s" % self._cluster_name) try: self._create_session() # Get cluster's mor from the given cluster name cluster_ref = vmware_util.get_cluster_ref_from_name( self._session, self._cluster_name) host_list = vmware_util.get_host_list_from_cluster_ref( self._session, cluster_ref) dvs_pg_list = vmware_util.get_dvs_pg_from_cluster( self._session, cluster_ref) def contains(list1, list2): for i in list2: if i not in list1: return False return True dvs_pg_info_list = [] for dvs_pg in dvs_pg_list: dvs_pg_name = vmware_util.get_dvs_pg_name( self._session, dvs_pg) hosts = vmware_util.get_host_on_dvpg( self._session, dvs_pg) dvs_pg_info = {} if contains(hosts, host_list): dvs = vmware_util.get_dvs_of_dvpg(self._session, dvs_pg) vlanid = vmware_util.get_vlan_of_dvpg( self._session, dvs_pg) if not isinstance(vlanid, list): dvs_pg_info = {"portgroup": dvs_pg_name, "vlanid": vlanid, "vswitchName": dvs} dvs_pg_dict = self._filter_portgroup_by_dict( dvs_pg_info) if len(dvs_pg_dict) > 0: dvs_pg_info_list.append(dvs_pg_dict) if len(dvs_pg_info_list) > 0: self._import_port_groups(dvs_pg_info_list) else: LOG.info("There are no port groups to import and update.") except exceptions.VimException as e: LOG.exception("Error occurred, message: %s" % e) self.import_dvs_port_groups()

added_lines: def test_assign_user_multiple_roles_by_unauthorized_user(self): # Non-administrator user should not be authorized to # assign multiple roles to user (user, tenant, default_role) = self._get_role_params() roles = self.data.roles for role in roles: self.assertRaises(exceptions.Unauthorized, self.non_admin_client.assign_user_role, tenant['id'], user['id'], role['id']) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_assign_user_multiple_roles_request_without_token(self): # Request to assign multiple roles to a user without a valid token (user, tenant, default_role) = self._get_role_params() roles = self.data.roles token = self.client.auth_provider.get_token() self.client.delete_token(token) for role in roles: self.assertRaises(exceptions.Unauthorized, self.client.assign_user_role, tenant['id'], user['id'], role['id']) self.client.auth_provider.clear_auth() @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_assign_user_multiple_roles_for_non_existent_roles(self): # Attempt to assign multiple non existent roles to user should fail (user, tenant, default_role) = self._get_role_params() roles = self.data.roles for role in roles: non_existent_role = str(uuid.uuid4().hex) self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.client.assign_user_role, tenant['id'], user['id'], non_existent_role) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_assign_user_multiple_roles_for_non_existent_tenant(self): # Attempt to assign multiple roles on a non existent tenant should fail (user, tenant, default_role) = self._get_role_params() non_existent_tenant = str(uuid.uuid4().hex) roles = self.data.roles for role in roles: self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.client.assign_user_role, non_existent_tenant, user['id'], role['id']) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_assign_multiple_duplicate_user_roles(self): # Multiple Duplicate user roles should not get assigned (user, tenant, default_role) = self._get_role_params() roles = self.data.roles for role in roles: self.client.assign_user_role(tenant['id'], user['id'], role['id']) self.assertRaises(exceptions.Conflict, self.client.assign_user_role, tenant['id'], user['id'], role['id']) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate'])

commit_message:
Propose: cache-neutron-security-groups

Continuation of bp: cache-neutron-security-groups

Change-Id: I12d38e7fb9e60663b228365f14013de97165c867
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/98/82598/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. .. ============================= cache-neutron-security-groups ============================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/decouple-neutron-security-groups Nova-api should be able to work if neutron is down. Currently this is not the case as we are going to neutron in order to obtain the security_groups on an instance. In this blueprint we'll cache these security groups in nova instead to avoid going to neutron. Problem description =================== Currently, whenever performing any GET options on nova for example nova list nova-api calls out to neutron in order to get a list of security groups attached to the instance. In addition, this is also done for most other api operations due to how nova's extension framework is implemented. For example, the nova interface-detach command will also cause nova-api to query neutron for the security groups attached to the instance. The problem, with this design is if neutron is down nova-api no longer works (as it fails trying to talk to neutron) in addition we are quering neutron a lot more then we need to be. Proposed change =============== In order to solve this issue I propose that we cache the security_groups attached to each VIF in the instance_info_caches table and return the security groups from there rather than from neutron. Alternatives ------------ REST API impact --------------- Nova-api should be slightly faster as it no longer calls out to neutron. In addition it's able to return data when neturon is down. Notifications impact -------------------- Other End user impact --------------------- If one adds a security group to a port via neturon and then queries nova the security_group just added to the instance might not be returned because nova has not yet updated it's cache yet. This is also true with adding a floatingip to an instance or changing the instances ip_address today. That said, with neutron sending nova events on port changes this security group should show up in nova pretty quickly. Deployer impact --------------- Developer impact ---------------- Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: arosen Milestones ---------- Originally approved for: Juno-1 Completed: None Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Documentation Impact ====================

commit_message:
Support passing 'neutron_insecure' to neutronclient

When using a self-signed certificate for the network service endpoint,
the metadata agent has to pass the 'insecure' flag to neutronclient.
Otherwise requests will fail due to the failed certificate validity
check.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1269740
Change-Id: I091b1620ab60184921cc12e038af5d717d4d476f

commit_message:
Poll the agent child processes status (WIP)

discovers the situation where a child process has died via
a health check, method and uses the process status implementation
to propagate the status to the parent of the agent.

partially implements blueprint agent-child-processes-status

commit_message:
Provide agent status via status file (WIP)

Exposes agent status to a file which can be queried by the parent,
this mechanism could be used to expose status conditions, like
lost broker connectivity, dying childs, or anomalous status.

implements blueprint agent-service-status

Change-Id: I0bcc9ba14a46a81b5f34ffbf43494da00188f5d5

added_lines: import csvimport ioclass StatusFile(object): def __init__(self,status_file): self._status_file = status_file try: self.fd = os.open(status_file, os.O_CREAT | os.RDWR) except IOError: LOG.exception(_("Failed to open status file: %s"), status_file) sys.exit(1) self.lock() self._register_file_cleanup() def __str__(self): return self._status_file def _register_file_cleanup(self): atexit.register(self._delete_file) def _delete_file(self): self.unlock() os.remove(str(self._status_file)) def lock(self): if fcntl.flock(self.fd, fcntl.LOCK_EX)!=0: raise IOError(_('Unable to lock status file: %s'),self._status_file) def unlock(self): if fcntl.flock(self.fd, fcntl.LOCK_UN)!=0: raise IOError(_('Unable to unlock status file: %s'), self._status_file) def update(self, status_data): # TODO(mangelajo): add a file semaphore while we update # status_file+'.lck', on which the init script # could lock also os.ftruncate(self.fd, 0) os.write(self.fd, status_data) os.fsync(self.fd) # TODO(mangelajo) remove the semaphore now that we're done class DaemonStatus(object): # error levels , higher = more critical INFO = 0 WARNING = 10 ERROR = 20 CRITICAL = 30 # error codes OK = 0 RPC_BROKER_DISCONNECTED = 10 CHILD_PROCESS_DIED = 20 # error codes to messages and levels STATUS = { OK: {'level': INFO, 'message': _('Service OK')}, RPC_BROKER_DISCONNECTED: {'level': CRITICAL, 'message': _("RPC Broker connectivity " "lost")}, CHILD_PROCESS_DIED: { 'level': ERROR, 'message': _('Child process died ' 'unexpectedly')} } def __init__(self,status_file): self._status_file = StatusFile(status_file) self._active_status = {} def _get_status_info(self, status_code): status_level = self.STATUS[status_code]['level'] status_message = self.STATUS[status_code]['message'] return status_level, status_message def set_status(self, status_code, extended_message = ""): level, message = self._get_status_info(status_code) self.active_status[status_code] = (level, message + extended_message) self._write_status() def clear_status(self, status_code): try: self.active_status.pop(status_code) except KeyError: level, message = self._get_status_info(status_code) LOG.warning(_("Trying to clear status code %d (%s) which wasn't " "set") % (status_code, message)) self._write_status() def get_status_csv(self): status_list_by_level = sorted(self._render_status_list(), key=lambda status: status[1], reversed=True) csv_str = io.StringIO() writer = csv.writer(csv_str) writer.writerow(['code', 'level', 'message']) for status in status_list_by_level: writer.writerow(status) return csv_str.getvalue() def _render_status_list(self): status_list = [] for status_code in self._active_status.keys(): level, message = self._get_status_info(status_code) status_list.append( (status_code, level, message) ) if len(status_list)==0: level, message = self._get_status_info(self.OK) status_list.append( (self.OK, level, message) ) return status_list def _write_status(self): status_csv = self.get_status_csv() self._status_file.update(status_csv)

commit_message:
Filter deployment status when building metadata

A deployment, no matter its status is 'IN_PROGRESS' or 'COMPLETE' is now
included into the metadata for a server.  This is incorrect.  When a
second deployment is applied to the same server, the pre-existing
deployments may be applied again.

This patch fixes the problem above by filtering out all deployments
whose status is not 'IN_PROGRESS'.  In other words, 'COMPLETE' or
'FAILED' deployment won't be deployed again after this patch is applied.

Change-Id: I9e1ffd9c06a011feaf960cf5ebb0eb0f7b28f637
Closes-Bug: #1300626

commit_message:
delete_on_termination strict parameter checking

Since this is such an important flag, strict checking of
configuration flags should be turned on (otherwise, what should
the behaviour of "3" be? etc). This also results in the
default behavior being False to prevent None values.

Change-Id: I65b6665d3c006845699f547cbd07e0564b5c46c3

commit_message:
Provide instructions for sample config without tox

In some cases, such as when building a package, you don't want to use
tox to generate a sample config.  Provide instructions for how to
generate the sample config using the local env and not a tox managed
virtual env.

Change-Id: Ie2291ffd7a541f0324ea8db611c70048df5372ab
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/33/82533/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $ tox -egenconfig If you need to generate the sample config file using dependencies installed locally and not via a tox managed virtual environment, use the following command: $ bash tools/config/generate_sample.sh -b . -p nova -o etc/nova

commit_message:
List all forbidden attributes in the request body.

When request content is validated by applying
cls.check_immutable_params() and an exception is
raised all forbidden parameters should be listed
in one response.

Change-Id: I15b3fa979bdb33bd341b0b99c1802af46273f358

revisions:

Closes-bug: #1304968

commit_message:
Read deleted instances during lifecycle events

This prevents us from failing to find the associated instance if
the lifecycle event happens after the instance has been deleted,
as in the case of a ... delete.

Change-Id: I819ddf8ff68edc407d7932bf43771c440f514f26
Closes-bug: #1304968

commit_message:
Add OSSN-0012 - OpenSSL Heartbleed vulnerability

This adds OSSN-0012, which covers the OpenSSL Heartbleed
vulnerability.  This isn't a vulnerability in OpenStack itself, but
OpenStack deployments are likely affected since they would be using
OpenSSL for SSL/TLS.

Change-Id: I2db43e23dc0b090887e937be6188b64e2a0a2ad5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack-attic/openstack-security-notes refs/changes/66/86466/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OpenSSL Heartbleed vulnerabilty can lead to OpenStack compromise --- ### Summary ### A vulnerability in OpenSSL can lead to leaking of key material and sensitive data protected by SSL/TLS in an OpenStack deployment. ### Affected Services / Software ### Grizzly, Havana, OpenSSL ### Discussion ### A vulnerability in OpenSSL code-named Heartbleed was recently discovered that can lead to leaking key material. Any data protected by these leaked keys may therefore be compromised as well. For full details, see the following website that describes this vulnerability in detail: http://heartbleed.com/ While OpenStack software itself is not directly affected, any deployment of OpenStack is very likely using OpenSSL to provide SSL/TLS functionality. ### Recommended Actions ### It is recommended that you immediately update OpenSSL software on the systems you use to run OpenStack services. In most cases, you will want to upgrade to OpenSSL version 1.0.1g, though it is recommended that you review the exact version details on the Heartbleed website referenced aboce. It is also recommended that you treat your existing SSL/TLS keys as compromised and generate new keys. This includes keys used to configure SSL/TLS protection for OpenStack API endpoints, message brokers, and libvirt remote access. In addition, any secondary key material such as passwords that has been sent over a SSL/TLS connection may have been compromised. It is recommended that you change these passwords, particularly for administrative users who have priviledged access. ### Contacts / References ### This OSSN : https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OSSN/OSSN-0012 OpenStack Security ML : openstack-security@lists.openstack.org OpenStack Security Group : https://launchpad.net/~openstack-ossg CVE: CVE-2014-0160

commit_message:
Use glance as a backend for Solum LanguagePack API (POST Method)

First step is to create an image in glance. Next step will be to
upload the image data. That's how it is done in glance.

The created image will be marked as "queued" until the data is
sent.

Fixes bug 1301441

Change-Id: I5871367b6869e3bd048061635ec562d080345eb8

deleted_lines: import uuid db_obj = objects.registry.LanguagePack() db_obj.update(data) db_obj.uuid = str(uuid.uuid4()) db_obj.user_id = self.context.user db_obj.project_id = self.context.tenant db_obj.create(self.context) return db_obj

commit_message:
Include proper Content-Type in the HTTP Headers

Nova Metadata Service was not setting the Content-Type
in the HTTP Response headers. Because of this, clients
were receiving the default Content-Type which is "text/html".
The changes done in this patch will include proper Content-Type
in the HTTP response headers.

Closes-Bug: #1243878
Change-Id: Ia65cdf8099c85f63d7f44f93835c606d679a7ab3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/12/76112/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: response_ctype = response.headers['Content-Type'] self.assertEqual(response_ctype.startswith("text/plain"), True) def test_json_data(self): response = fake_request(self.stubs, self.mdinst, "/openstack/latest/meta_data.json") response_ctype = response.headers['Content-Type'] self.assertEqual(response_ctype.startswith("application/json"), True) response = fake_request(self.stubs, self.mdinst, "/openstack/latest/vendor_data.json") response_ctype = response.headers['Content-Type'] self.assertEqual(response_ctype.startswith("application/json"), True) response_ctype = response.headers['Content-Type'] self.assertEqual(response_ctype.startswith("text/plain"), True) response_ctype = response.headers['Content-Type'] self.assertEqual(response_ctype.startswith("text/plain"), True)

commit_message:
Add db2-server and db2-client recipe

There are no changes in current files and attributes,
since db2 cookbook is not available for all users.

Change-Id: Ie2cb1907b9e405e4b7ac7ad0f37872ecd13cee23
Implements: blueprint db2-reference-impl
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-ops-database refs/changes/85/85985/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ## db2-client ## - installs db2 odbc driver package, only available on redhat platform. ## db2-server ## - installs db2 server, creates db2 database and users, only available on redhat platform.
